title: Force on current - ratio of force per unit length

content.question: Two long straight, parallel wires are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, where <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> is much smaller than the length of the wires. The magnetic force per unit length exerted on each wire from the other at this distance is <math alttext="open parenthesis, uppercase F over L, close parenthesis, sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mpadded><mi>F</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>L</mi></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mi>i</mi></msub></math>. If the distance between the wires is increased to <math alttext="2 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></math> and each of the currents is reduced to <math alttext="uppercase I over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, the new magnetic force per length between the wires is <math alttext="open parenthesis, uppercase F over L, close parenthesis, sub lowercase f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mpadded><mi>F</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>L</mi></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mi>f</mi></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="the complex fraction with numerator open parenthesis, uppercase F over L, close parenthesis, sub lowercase f, and denominator open parenthesis, uppercase F over L, close parenthesis, sub lowercase i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>F</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>L</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mi>f</mi></msub><mpadded><msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>F</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>L</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>i</mi></msub></mpadded></mfrac></math>?
